results.title: [Genetically modified crops]
results.brief_description: This video contains no title or credits and appears to be a compilation of documentary programs produced by the BBC on the subject of Genetically Modified Foods. It begins in the mid-west of the United States where one-third of the soya bean crops are genetically modified and farmers are becoming angry and confused, questioning the costs and yields of GM crops. Where Europe and many other global nations have made the decision to go slow in introducing GM crops, the United States on the other hand have rushed in and agressively promoted the use of biotechnology to their farmers, particularly with soya bean and corn production. Farmers, especially those involved in organic farming, fear cross-contamination from property to property through the spread of pollen from the GM crops. The program then crosses to Oxfordshire in the UK where tests are being carried out by Friends of the Earth on the control of pollen flow from engineered crops and then finally to India where corporations such as Monsanto are pushing the Indian Government to allow GM crop growing by the farmers which would ultimately turn into a multi-billion dollar business for the likes of Monsanto and their partners. As with farmers, consumers are also becoming aware of the inherent dangers, environmentally and genetically, and are protesting all around the world. A very interesting and informative program. NB: Sound quality is uneven and of poor quality in parts.

results.title: [Farmyard follies]
results.brief_description: A collection of back-to-back “old-time hillbilly favourites” sung by singers in “hillbilly” costume. Songs include: “I Love Mountain Music”, “I Sold My Saddle for an Old Guitar” plus routines.

results.title: [Fanfare shorts]
results.brief_description: A showreel anthology of animated advertisements and public service films from the early to mid 1960’s. Zippy and sophisticated animation at the service of commerce and public education. These cartoons provide a facinating insight into the social and cultural mores of ‘60’s Australia.

results.title: [Events of 1935]
results.brief_description: Untitled newsreel footage of the 1935 Southport Flower Show in the UK showing various activities. Also includes scenes of the Southport Lawn Tennis Championships won by H. Ellsworth Vines and W.T. Tilden (USA), horse jumping events and the Birkdale Golf Club House.

results.title: [Elmer elephant]
results.creator_credit: Wilfred Jackson, Walt Disney and Walt Disney Animation Studios
results.brief_description: A “Silly Symphony” animated story about how the animals ridicule Elmer’s long nose until he saves the day by using his trunk to extinguish a fire. Opening title missing.

results.title: [Edvard Munch 1863-1944]
results.brief_description: The story of Edvard Munch, the artist, with narration and music accompanied by his won painting. A hectic and difficult life where he was seldom understood. His style was continuously changing and his main themes were love and death.
results.description: The story of Edvard Munch, the artist, with narration and music accompanied by his won painting. A hectic and difficult life where he was seldom understood. His style was continuously changing and his main themes were love and death.

results.title: [Eat LOUD carpet compilation]
results.creator_credit: LOUD Media Festival of Youth Culture and the Arts
results.brief_description: A collection of four short films from the SBS program, “Eat Carpet”, in which things aren’t always as they seem. “Goth to be Greek”, directed by Andrew Georgiou and Tim Slade, is the story of a goth who finally finds a woman who wears black and hangs out in cemeteries. “Bad news”, directed by Sofya Gollan, tells the tale of a profoundly deaf couple who react in an unexpected way after hearing some news from their apologetic doctor. “Skater, homie, skeggy, wog”, directed by Andrew Dowell and Brendan Dowell, focuses on some of the myths and misconceptions that teens from rival suburbs have regarding each other’s dress and way of living. “How black is black?”, directed by Jade Woods (aged 13), looks at the identity crises suffered by fair-skinned Koories.

An animated fireworks performance over Sydney Harbour Bridge.

An animated short entered to “Create a Stamp Story” section of ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.
